steps.title: Know the food items involved in the dish:
steps.content: Know the food items involved in the dish: Puri : the round, hollow, crispy bite-sized balls Masala : filling of mashed or semi-mashed potato/chickpea, spiced Pani : choice of sweet chutney, sour, salted or spicy water

steps.title: Prepare the puri.
steps.content: Prepare the puri. Take the puri in your non-dominant hand and poke a hole in it using your thumb or a spoon.

steps.title: Add the filling.
steps.content: Add the filling. Take some filling in a spoon or your dominant hand and put it inside the puri through the hole. You can adjust the spices and chillies of the masala, if required.

steps.title: Choose a pani.
steps.content: Choose a pani. Either dip the stuffed puri in a bowl of pani or pour some pani inside it using a spoon or a ladle. You can use more than one type of pani. The common choice is to use the sweet chutney along with another kind of pani.

steps.title: Eat it immediately.
steps.content: Eat it immediately. Take it all in one bite. Don't let it get soggy, or the ball will break down. Repeat the same with more puris.

steps.title: End your meal.
steps.content: End your meal. Traditionally, a pani puri meal is ended with a sukha. To make a sukha, prepare the crispiest puri with a hole and stuff it with the masala. Now, instead of adding any pani, add more spices to it with a small squeeze of lime and garnish it with finely chopped cilantro and sprinkles of bhujiya (local snack item). Eat it immediately.

steps.title: Find a street vendor.
steps.content: Find a street vendor. The more popular way of eating pani puri is when someone serves you, especially the small stall owners by the streets.

steps.title: Ask for the price and bargain a bit.
steps.content: Ask for the price and bargain a bit. (It's traditional). Remember, the prices are different in different places and bargaining does not always yield results.

steps.title: Receive your bowl.
steps.content: Receive your bowl. You will be given a small bowl made of plastic or paper or dried leaves.

steps.title: Choose a masala if there are variants.
steps.content: Choose a masala if there are variants. You might get a choice between potato and chickpeas. You can opt for both if the stall-owner is open to it.

steps.title: Take one bite and ask the stall-keeper to adjust the masala to your taste.
steps.content: Take one bite and ask the stall-keeper to adjust the masala to your taste. Commonly, people ask to adjust the salt and the chili.

steps.title: Choose a pani.
steps.content: Choose a pani. You can generally choose between a tamarind water or a mint water or a cumin-lime water.

steps.title: Ask the vendor for the sweet chutney if you like your pani puri to be on the sweeter side.
steps.content: Ask the vendor for the sweet chutney if you like your pani puri to be on the sweeter side.

steps.title: Wait for your dish.
steps.content: Wait for your dish. After assembling everything, s/he will serve you in your bowl. Some stall-keepers offer you finely chopped or diced onions which you will be given in your bowl. You can add some onions to each puri before you eat it.

steps.title: Pick it up using your thumb and your index finger.
steps.content: Pick it up using your thumb and your index finger. Support it with your middle finger and eat it in one bite.
